title: John Doughty
text:
John Doughty (July 25, 1754September 16, 1826) was an American military officer who briefly served as the <a href="Commanding%20General%20of%20the%20United%20States%20Army">senior officer of the United States Army</a> in 1784. Holding the rank of <a href="major">major</a> at the time, he bears the distinction of being the lowest ranked individual ever to serve as the senior most United States Army officer.
Biography.
Born in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> on July 25, 1754, he graduated from King's College (<a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a>) in 1770 and entered military service through New Jersey state channels in January 1776.
American Revolution.
He served as adjutant general of two <a href="Morris%20County%2C%20New%20Jersey">Morris County</a> battalions and was appointed <a href="captain%20lieutenant">captain lieutenant</a> of the <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a> Eastern Artillery Company in March 1776. Doughty became a captain of the <a href="2nd%20Continental%20Artillery%20Regiment">2nd Continental Artillery Regiment</a> in January 1777 and served as an <a href="aide-de-camp">aide-de-camp</a> to <a href="Major%20General">Major General</a> <a href="Philip%20Schuyler">Philip Schuyler</a>. Later, he was assigned to command the New York State Artillery Company in March 1777.
Doughty would participate in the battles of <a href="Battle%20of%20Brandywine">Brandywine</a> (1777), <a href="Battle%20of%20Germantown">Germantown</a> (1777), <a href="Battle%20of%20Monmouth">Monmouth</a> (1778), <a href="Battle%20of%20Springfield%20%281780%29">Springfield</a> (1780), and <a href="Siege%20of%20Yorktown">Yorktown</a> (1781). He was appointed brigade major of the Corps of Artillery in 1779 and was appointed fort major for the <a href="West%20Point">West Point</a> garrison in 1782. He was transferred to the Corps of Artillery in June 1783 and was promoted to brevet <a href="major">major</a> in September. Doughty's artillery company was attached to Henry Jackson's <a href="1st%20American%20Regiment%20%281783%E2%80%931784%29">1st American Regiment</a> following in the disbanding of the <a href="Continental%20Army">Continental Army</a> late in 1783.
Post Revolution.
Doughty became the Army's senior ranking officer following the discharge of Jackson's regiment in June 1784, leaving Doughty in command of a company of 55 artillerymen at <a href="West%20Point">West Point</a> and a detachment of 25 men at <a href="Fort%20Pitt%20%28Pennsylvania%29">Fort Pitt</a> in Pennsylvania guarding military stores left over from the Continental Army.
On August 12 of the same year, an <a href="First%20American%20Regiment">Infantry regiment</a> was organized under Brevet Brigadier General <a href="Josiah%20Harmar">Josiah Harmar</a>, who then became the senior officer in the United States Army. On that date, Doughty was promoted to major and placed in command of a battalion of two companies of artillery. In this position he superintended the construction of <a href="Fort%20Harmar">Fort Harmar</a> (1785) and <a href="Fort%20Washington%20%28Cincinnati%2C%20Ohio%29">Fort Washington</a> (1789) on the Ohio frontier.
Doughty was designated major commandant of the <a href="Early%20U.S.%20Artillery%20formations">Battalion of Artillery</a> in September 1789, and then was dispatched by <a href="George%20Washington">President Washington</a> to the frontier to negotiate with the <a href="Choctaw">Choctaw</a> Nation for trading post sites in 1789. He was repelled with serious losses when attacked by <a href="Cherokee">Cherokee</a>, <a href="Shawnee">Shawnee</a>, and <a href="Muscogee">Muscogee</a> people, while leading a detachment up the <a href="Tennessee%20River">Tennessee River</a> on a negotiating mission to the <a href="Chickasaw">Chickasaw</a> Nation in 1790.
In March 1791 Doughty was offered the position of lieutenant colonel commandant (i.e. commanding officer) of the newly formed <a href="2nd%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">2nd Infantry Regiment</a>. Doughty declined the appointment and decided to retire from the Army instead.
Doughty was appointed brigadier general of artillery, 2d Division, New Jersey militia in 1793 and was appointed lieutenant colonel, <a href="Early%20U.S.%20Artillery%20formations">2d Regiment of Artillerists and Engineers</a>, as <a href="Quasi-War">war with France</a> threatened in June 1798.
In May 1800 Doughty resigned from the Army and returned to private life on his estate at <a href="Morristown%2C%20New%20Jersey">Morristown, New Jersey</a>, to engage in agriculture and pursue literary studies. He died there on September 16, 1826. He is buried in the First Presbyterian Church Cemetery in Morristown.
